channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Customers lament Tesla’s move toward monthly fees for self-driving cars: ‘You will own nothing and be happy’
item.description: Elon Musk announced Tesla would no longer allow outright purchases of self-driving software, and users aren't happy.

item.title: Oracle struggles to attract workers to Nashville ‘world HQ’—even with a 2-million-square-foot office and Larry Ellison’s favorite restaurant
item.description: Years after cofounder Larry Ellison declared Nashville its world headquarters, Oracle has added only a handful of workers.

item.title: None of Mamdani’s Deputy Mayors Are Black. It Has Become a Problem.
item.description: Some Black and Latino leaders worry they are being denied access to power under Mayor Zohran Mamdani and that they may lose the ground they had gained...

item.title: Worried about AI taking your job? New Anthropic research shows it’s not that simple
item.description: Anthropic’s latest data suggests AI won’t wipe out work overnight—but it will redraw the map of who wins, who struggles, and how jobs actually change.

item.title: Trump Outlines Health Care Proposals as Prices and Premiums Rise
item.description: The long-awaited plan would leave much to Congress and calls for payments to health savings accounts rather than insurance subsidies, among other broa...

item.title: Nick Reiner Was in a Mental Health Conservatorship in 2020
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who is accused of killing his parents, was under a yearlong legal arrangement that allows for involuntary psychiatric treatment.

item.title: Big Plan for Fannie and Freddie I.P.O. in Flux as Trump Pushes Affordability
item.description: Six months after President Trump told Wall Street banks to prepare a swift stock offering, there is no firm plan for how to take the giant mortgage fi...

item.title: ‘They’re going to have to think and act a lot more like hotels’: The new rules of office space now that the ‘genie is out of the bottle on hybrid’
item.description: From cold plunges to nap pods to meditation rooms, many employers are turning to luxury to lure in their workers.

item.title: Appeals Court Opens the Door to Mahmoud Khalil’s Rearrest
item.description: Any new detention would not come immediately, and Mr. Khalil’s lawyers plan to appeal. But the ruling is a major blow to Mr. Khalil, a Columbia gradua...

item.title: Exclusive: Former OpenAI policy chief creates nonprofit institute, calls for independent safety audits of frontier AI models
item.description: Former OpenAI policy head Miles Brundage debuts AVERI, an institute advocating for independent safety audits of top AI models

item.title: Iran Denies Sentencing Protester to Death Amid International Outcry
item.description: Iran denied sentencing a protester, Erfan Soltani, 26, to death. Soltani’s case had drawn intense international attention after his relatives and righ...

item.title: Uganda’s Election Goes Ahead, Despite Major Delays at the Polls
item.description: Technical failures at polling places caused major disruptions, and the opposition has warned of protests and government vote rigging.

item.title: Remains of 32 Cubans Killed in U.S. Strikes in Venezuela Are Returned
item.description: State-run television aired a ceremony for the remains of 32 Cuban citizens killed in the U.S. strikes in Venezuela arriving in Havana. The deceased we...

item.title: Israel and Arab Nations Ask Trump to Refrain From Attacking Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asked the president to postpone any planned attack. Israeli and Arab officials fear Iran could retaliate b...

item.title: Cuba Receives Remains of 32 Citizens Killed in U.S. Strikes in Venezuela
item.description: The Cubans had served as part of the security detail of Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s ousted president.
